misconceptions.name: Solving a different physics acceleration problem instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The program is entirely focused on computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t rather than reading 5 integers, filtering even numbers, and summing them.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then compute and print the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read 5 integers from the user, use logic (e.g., a loop and an if-condition) to select only the even numbers, accumulate their sum, and then print the sum of those even numbers.
symptoms: The input prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of "5 integers".
The code reads exactly three double values, not five integers.
There is no loop or repeated structure to handle 5 inputs.
There is no conditional check for even numbers (no use of % 2).
The computation is (V1 - V0) / T, which is an acceleration formula, not a sum.
The output message reports "The average acceleration" instead of "Sum of even numbers".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion of assignments or reuse of a textbook/example solution for an acceleration problem without adapting it to the current specification about summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words. Then design the algorithm: (1) read 5 integers, (2) for each number, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) if even, add it to a running sum, and (4) after processing all 5 numbers, print the sum of the even ones.
related_concepts: Using loops to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every key element of the code (prompt, variable names, arithmetic formula, and output message) corresponds to a standard acceleration example and none of the required behaviors for summing even integers are present.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output are about average acceleration (v0, v1, t) and do not implement reading 5 integers, checking evenness, or summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Loop for Multiple Inputs
misconceptions.description: Code lacks any loop structure. It reads only 3 individual values with separate statements instead of using a loop to read 5 inputs iteratively.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that individual variable assignments are sufficient to handle reading multiple inputs, rather than recognizing the need for a loop when the number of inputs is fixed and greater than 2-3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When reading a fixed number of inputs (5 integers), a loop (for or while) should be used to read them efficiently. This demonstrates understanding of iteration patterns.
symptoms: Exactly 3 hardcoded INPUT calls instead of looped reads
No for loop or while loop present
Cannot handle any variation in input count
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not yet understand loop patterns for reading collections of similar data, or may have copied code without adapting it.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop: `for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = INPUT.nextInt(); ... }` to read 5 integers repeatedly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absence of any loop is objectively verifiable in the code. The student clearly did not use a loop construct.

evidence.note: Three separate hardcoded INPUT calls instead of a loop. Should iterate 5 times to read 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Modulo Logic for Even/Odd Testing
misconceptions.description: Code contains no modulo operator and no conditional logic to test whether a number is even. The core filtering requirement is completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that no conditional filtering is needed, or they submitted code for a different problem and did not adapt it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To identify even numbers, use the modulo operator: `if(n % 2 == 0)` checks if n is divisible by 2 (remainder is 0). Only even numbers should be included in the sum.
symptoms: No modulo (%) operator appears in code
No if statement for filtering numbers
No conditional logic of any kind for data processing
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem (acceleration) that doesn't require such filtering logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a conditional check: `if(num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; }` inside your input loop to accumulate only even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The modulo operator and any filtering conditional are completely absent from the code. This is not ambiguous.

evidence.snippet:
double A = (V1 - V0) / T;

      System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + A);
evidence.note: Code performs arithmetic calculation on three variables with no conditional logic or modulo checks for even/odd filtering.

misconceptions.name: Implements an average-acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student program solves a completely different problem (computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) instead of reading 5 integers, summing only the even ones, and printing that sum. As a result, there is no loop over 5 inputs, no even-number check, and no accumulator for the sum of evens.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to prompt for initial velocity, final velocity, and time, compute average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t, and print that result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user (or otherwise read) 5 integers, iterate over these values (e.g., with a loop), use a conditional to check whether each number is even (n % 2 == 0), maintain a running total of the even numbers only, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by that sum.
symptoms: Prompt string asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Program reads exactly three values using nextDouble() instead of five integers.
Variables are named V0, V1, T, and A, representing physics quantities rather than generic integers to be summed.
Core computation is (V1 - V0) / T, with no loop, no modulus (%) operation, and no running sum of even numbers.
Output message is "The average acceleration is ..." instead of "Sum of even numbers: ...".
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student reused or submitted code for a different textbook exercise (average acceleration) or misread the assignment instructions, so they implemented the wrong algorithm rather than misunderstanding Java syntax or specific constructs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the current physics-specific logic and re-start from the problem statement: design a solution that reads exactly 5 integers, uses a loop to process all inputs, checks each with n % 2 == 0, accumulates a sum of only the even ones, and then prints that sum in the required format.
related_concepts: Translating problem requirements into code structure
Using loops to process multiple inputs
Basic program specification reading and task alignment
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure (prompt text, variable names, formula, and output) matches the standard "average acceleration" example and contains none of the elements needed for the even-sum problem, strongly indicating the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t), computes average acceleration A = (V1 - V0) / T, and prints "The average acceleration is ...", which is unrelated to reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.
